text: the pórtico quartet cortical quartet hi
everyone
Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review
the pórtico quartets new self-titled LP
the these guys are a london-based band
and this is their third full-length
studio album and this LP has a nice
blend of ideas coming from the worlds of
jazz and electronic music and it's not
like electronics and jazz haven't met
before over the years there have been
tons of musicians bringing these two
worlds together among tobin as well as
this is for tet in some of his solo
stuff and in collaborations he's done
and one of my favorite electronic music
producers of all time Square pusher
those guys are just single producers and
and and producing music by yourself
definitely has a different sound than
when you're working with a full band but
it's not like that
combination of jazz and electronic music
hasn't been explored either by groups
like the Cinematic Orchestra Norway's
jaga jazz
and I'm not trying to say the pórtico
quartet is late to the party when it
comes to combining jazz and electronics
I just feel like their music and this
album is kind of like the next phase of
this combo now while this record does
not sound like the cool or the Bebop
or the fusion that a lot of jazz nuts go
crazy over it does embrace a lot of jazz
elements like interplay between the
musicians improvisation and exploration
musically and sonically previous
material from the span especially their
own 9 album isla was much smoother and
had kind of a an escalating post-rock
quality to it with a lot of strong sax
solo
in a way it kind of reminded me of bands
like fridge and producers like new
japaese at the same time now this new LP
sees the band's style evolving and maybe
in a way that will turn off some of the
more traditional jazz fans that have
latched on to their sound there are some
tracks on here that completely function
without the aid of sax solos there are
some spots on here where the sax does
kind of steal the spotlight but for the
most part it's either not here or it's
playing performing in a way where it is
just adding another texture another
sound soaring above all of these layers
of beats of drums of synthesizers of
strings loops and samples to the
electronics are kind of taking over with
this album and they're now using them to
improvise and to experiment much more
there was even one track on here that I
remember had kind of a drum solo going
with an MPC take the track ruins for
example which is kind of one of the more
direct tracks on this LP it's got a nice
straightforward groove a great upright
bass line
the bass is kind of being strummed and
there are all these soft ambient sound
scape textures just playing behind all
of this and then this very emotive sax
solo kind of just makes its way into the
track very shyly it's it's kind of
coming out of it's shell slowly but
surely and when the reverb eventually
hits this sax solo it just becomes
gargantuan there is some evolution going
on toward the end of the track that
really kind of makes me feel like who
this band is definitely in a different
spot now these looped synthesizer
arpeggios start coming in and as the sax
solo becomes really noisy and kind of
chaotic all of these glitchy harsh loud
electronics just start barreling down on
the track making it really kind of
intense I like it because this track
really feels like a full band
I hear improvisation 'z I hear interplay
between the musicians but the way the
track is built with this really
repetitive
these electronic elements it kind of
feels like it borrows its structure from
an electronic dance song the third track
on here kind of follows the same premise
as that second one which which acts me a
little bit but it's still a decent song
the band really kind of starts
stretching its legs out in this new
direction on the fourth track rubidium
which embarks on this eight-minute
soundscape of of electronic textures
tense strings really faint horns and
some synth loops too then these drums
just unexpectedly fly in and just start
going all Art Blakey drum solo all over
the place rolls and fills as far as the
ear can hear it's pretty formless and
vast and even though it is that it just
has so many beautiful sounds in it and
leaves me with so much to think about
the sixth track lacquer vu is a bit more
straightforward the beat is mostly
electronic very repetitive very hypnotic
I would call it almost a micro house
song if it wasn't for the fact that it
had these really kind of post-rock
violins sort of wailing over it I just
wish you had more of a climax to it the
song ste plus right after though is
fantastic one of my favourite tracks on
here brings this album into more of a
downtempo sound and has a guest vocalist
cornelia a swedish singer and her voice
is really light really fragile and
emotive has kind of a joanna newsom
quality to it this LP does take a bit of
a risk introducing a vocal guest so late
so close to the end but it really pays
off peridot put the vocals are just this
percussion played mostly by just the
drumsticks hitting each other and these
loops that are just kind of skipping
along in this in the sort of tense way
it feels like somebody hummed and then
took the hum and then sampled it and
chopped it up really quick so it just
kind of had this glitchy quality to it I
just wish a two-minute ambient interlude
wasn't how this band chose to end this
album it just felt extreme
the anti-climactic especially since the
the interlude didn't really seem to
connect to anything but maybe this band
isn't one for a big finish still I think
it's pretty interesting that the pórtico
quartet chose to make its third
full-length album self-titled and I
definitely feel that that's because
these guys are really defining
themselves on this album they really
jump from one style to the other which
normally would make an album feel really
disjointed but I feel like Portico
quartet gets away with it because every
track here is executed with roughly the
same instrumentation and sounds and the
mood pretty much stays the same
throughout this LP every track on this
album feels so calculated refined but
most importantly I think every single
track on the saddle bum is very
contemplative it's a very cerebral album
it's not an LP that gets my blood
pumping but my gears turning up here so
some great sounds great production and
recording wasn't huge on the ending
lukewarm on a few tracks but still I
think this is a fantastic album that
should be checked out definitely feeling
a strong eight to a light nine on this
album portico quartet self-titled LP
what do you think about it let me know
because I am interested do you love it
do you hate it why and what should I
review next anthony Fantino portico
quartet forever
